div.p: 1. IV:15. Saturday.

Visited my Garden, Nursery and Seminary, morning and afternoon— Dwarf Apples ripe— Horse-plums almost—headed down three Apple-trees from Medford, transplanted October 1830, and girdled in the winter of 1835–36 by field-mice.— They have all put out numerous shoots below the girdle, all which Kirk now reduced to one, and sawed off the stock of the old tree at the point where the new shoot issued from the stump, covering the top surface of the remainder stock, with the wax composition—and practiced the same process on the stump of a peach-tree, winter killed—the same winter of 1835–36. to the ground, but from which a new shoot issued the next Summer— This day was almost wholly consumed in revising the pamphlet fragment Speech making with the preface and supplement 130 pages, and in despatching copies—one to each town in the 12th. Congressional District— This afternoon Mr Joseph Harrington, and Mr Charles Knapp Dillaway, a Classmate of Harvard of my Son Charles, came as a Committee from the Roxbury Lyceum, to request me to deliver a Lecture before them— I excused myself as well as I could with the same reasons which I have given to others— The repetition of this same plea so continually is very mortifying— My wife, Mrs Smith and Mary, with her daughter Mary-Louisa, took tea, and we all spent the Evening at Charles’s— His second son Charles, is quite ill—keeping bed, and attended this day by Dr Woodward— Miss French brought me this afternoon a printed billet, signed the Ladies of Quincy, soliciting the company of my wife and me, at four O’Clock in the afternoon to a Pic Nic party, at the Hancock lot— This is a sequel to the Hingham party at Tranquility grove; intended to do me honour, and for which I ought to be warmly grateful; but for which I am so ill suited, that it greatly distresses me— I had a Letter too from Ichabod Morton of Plymouth urging me to attend the Convention at Hanover next Monday, which I finally concluded to do— We spent the Evening at Charles’s.
2. IV:30. Sunday.

Mr Robbins, Minister of a Church in Hanover Street, Boston, the same where Dr Lathrop formerly officiated, was the preacher for Mr Lunt this day— His morning text was from 2. Peter 3.5. “(For this they willingly are ignorant of, that) by the word of God, the heavens were of old, and the earth standing out of the water, and in the water: 6. Whereby the world that then was, being overflowed with water, perished: 7. But the heavens and the earth, which are now, by the same word are kept in store, reserved unto fire, against the day of judgment, and perdition of ungodly men— 13. Nevertheless, we, according to his promise, look for new heavens and a new earth, wherein dwelleth righteousness.”— A Dissertation, ingenious and not less devout upon the place where heaven is located—and an argument upon the purification of matter in the future world— A subject awfully perplexing, how matter can be refined into unchangeable existence, and where the locality of Heaven or the abode of the Soul in its future state, can be fixed— Mr Robbins cited numerous passages in the New Testament, bearing upon this subject, and seeming to be explanatory of the
of the difficulties— He dined with us, and preached in the afternoon from Luke 8.17.— [“]For nothing is secret that shall not be made manifest; neither any thing hid that shall not be known and come abroad.” On returning home from meeting this afternoon I found Mrs John Angier, and Elizabeth C Adams here— Mrs Angier returns to Medford to-morrow Morning— Coll. Josiah Quincy junr. was here this Evening, and so absorbed was my time the whole day that I lost my usual reading of a Sermon of Saurin— Charles and his wife passed the Evening here.
3. IV:30. Monday
Visit to Hanover, Plymouth County, and return to Quincy.

At 5. O’Clock this morning, I was at French’s tavern, when the Stage from Boston to Plymouth drove up and took the mail; and delivered one— There was not a single passenger, and I entered the Stage alone. At Hingham, one other person joined me, and at Scituate one more—both of whom remained Strangers to me— The passenger from Hingham, like myself was going to Hanover four Corners, to attend the Convention of the Plymouth County Association for the improvement of Common Schools. The distance from Quincy by this road is 18 miles 6. to Hingham 6. to Scituate and 6. to Hanover— We reached the tavern here about half past 7. and I had time to breakfast before any other of the visitors to attend the Convention arrived— They came in shortly afterwards— The meeting was held in the Episcopal Church, and was opened at ten O’Clock, by a prayer for the Revd. Thomas Robbins, a Trinitarian congregational clergyman of Mattapoisett, part of Rochester— Then Mr Nathaniel M. Davis of Plymouth, President of the Plymouth County Association for the improvement of common Schools, standing in the chancel announced the objects of the meeting; which were to choose Officers of the Association for the ensuing year— To hear an Address from Mr Horace Mann, the Secretary of the board of Education, and to consider certain proposals of the board with reference to the establishment of a normal School, or School for the Education of Teachers of common Schools—a Committee was appointed to report a list of Officers; they reported the re-election of those of the last year with the exception of the Revd. Charles Brooks of Hingham, as Secretary, he having requested to be excused from serving longer in that capacity. The report of the Committee was unanimously accepted, and then Mr Mann delivered his Address; which occupied nearly two hours.— It gave a rapid sketch of the recent proceedings of the Legislature, relating to Education— The formation of the board of Education, and the annual returns through them to the Legislature of all the Common Schools in the State— He referred to the antient institutions for Education from the earliest Settlement of the Colony, and pointed out many of the deficiencies both of the teachers and mode of teaching of the present time— It was about half after 12 when Mr Mann finished— A motion was immediately made by Mr Ryder to adjourn for an hour which was carried— The Stage from Plymouth to Boston stop’d on its way at Hanover just after one, and I was about to take my passage in it, when the Revd. George Putnam, a minister of Roxbury, and a member of the board of Education, offered me a Seat in his Chaise in which he would be alone— As he was to pass directly by my house I accepted the offer, and after dining at the hotel, attended the afternoon meeting at the Church— Extemporaneous Addresses were there made by
by Mr Ichabod Morton of Plymouth, Mr Robert Rantoul junr and the Revd. George Putnam, the two latter being members of the board of Education; after which I was requested to address the auditory— I made such excuses as I could to decline, but after much importunity consented—utterly destitute of the talent of extemporaneous public speaking on subjects with which I am not familiarly acquainted, and conscious that my information upon the subject under discussion was exceedingly imperfect, I spoke with shame and mortification—for about ten minutes— I apologised for my ignorance, and talked at random, referring unconnectedly to such observations of the preceding Speakers as occurred to me while speaking— In extemporising heretofore, I had found the principal difficulty to consist in having a closing remark always at hand and adaptable to any part of the address, to take off the awkwardness of an abrupt termination or of making periods in the midst of sentences—while I was sitting in the pew, thinking how if I should be obliged to speak, I could conclude, the idea occurred to me of the Spartan festival mentioned by Plutarch in his Life of Lycurgus, at which the three Choirs of Old men, middle aged, and children, boasted of their prowess, each in a couplet, and not recollecting how they were translated by Langhorne, and the other English translator, I put the ideas into three short English couplets of my own, and wrote them with a pencil, on a Letter cover, and from that moment had no more concern about my Speech— When pressed to speak, so that I could no longer decline, I took the stand in the chancel, and rambled about between apology and desultory remark, without method or point, till I began to be tedious; and then finished by telling the story of the Spartan festival and the three Choirs of Old men, middle aged, and boys— I said the Choirister of the old man was I supposed of about my age, as I was if not the oldest man present very nearly so— And that he speaking for all the old men of the Country said as might be rendered in our language

lg.l: We, have been in days of old
Wise and generous, brave and bold

div.p: Whereupon the representative of the men in the prime of life, about the age of the gentleman who was about the age of the Gentleman who was to succeed me, (D. Webster) said

lg.l: That, which in days of yore, ye were
We, at the present moment are.

div.p: And then a blooming boy, such as I had no doubt more than one could be found in the present assembly rose and said

lg.l: We promise to surpass you all.

div.p:
A shout of Laughter, and a thundering clap of hands followed, and I returned to the pew where I had been sitting at the side of Mr Webster, who said—well you have turned Plutarch to good account— It was something like a coincidence that while I had been hitching together these couplets he had asked me if I remembered a certain remark in Langhorne’s preface to his Plutarch which I did not— But I said I had read and admired Langhorne’s pre—in which he concurred— He was suffering with a very severe Catarrhal cold— When pressed to speak, he declined quite as earnestly as I had done. But he too was constrained, and addressed the auditory for about a quarter of an hour— He was for a reform in the teaching of the Common Schools, and said that the fault of the instructions was in teaching words instead
instead of things— He said also that all the elementary instruction that he had ever received before he entered college was at the Common Schools. He spoke with energy, and power, and as an occasional inhabitant of Marshfield in the County of Plymouth, was in favour of the establishment of the Normal School; and would cheerfully pay his proportion for it— This expense is the only difficulty to be gotten over; for it finally appeared that of all the towns to which the specific proposal had been made to provide for the expence, by a proportional contribution of a loan at a nominal interest; only two had accepted— One had positively rejected it, and from the rest no answer had been received. The meeting adjourned between five and six, and I came home with Mr Putnam; who stop’d and took tea at our house. We came home through Weymouth which abridges the distance about two miles— We found my wife and Charles at tea—but Mrs Smith—Louisa, Mary and Charles wife were at Mrs T. B. Adams’s, where I soon after went, and was followed by Charles and Mr E Price Greenleaf. Walked home with him— The day was fine; but the morning and evening so cold, that with my thick Winter Cloak I was barely comfortable— Besides the persons already named I met at Hanover William Thomas of Plymouth—Revd. Samuel J. May, Anthony Collamore of Pembroke and Mr Lemuel Capen.
4. IV:30. Tuesday

list.item: Ladies of Quincy— Pic-Nic and Ball.

div.p:
Joseph H. Adams and his Sister Mrs Angier stop’d here this morning. She was returning home to Medford— The dissipation of yesterday encroached upon the time of this day, and threw me again into arrears— It was not until this time that I could complete the revisal of the fragment pamphlet; to send back one revised copy to Mr Gales and one to Lewis Tappan of New-York, which I did— The Pic Nic and Ball given by the Ladies of Quincy was on this day, with great formality, and with the intention of shewing respect to me and to my wife— The hour fixed in the printed invitation was four in the afternoon. The place was a lot of Land given by my father to the Town of Quincy, and called the Hancock lot, because the cellar still remains upon it of the House in which John Hancock was born— Soon after four Mr Ibrahim Bartlett, and Mr Lloyd G. Horton came as a deputation from the company to enquire at what time it would suit me to join them— I said immediately— My wife with Mrs W. S. Smith, Louisa C. Smith and Mary had already gone— Mr Bartlett and Mr Horton returned to the company, and then came back and escorted me to the entrance of the lot where I was received by six young unmarried Ladies between whom I was conducted to the large Lime-tree in the centre of the lot—there received by two married Ladies who presented me to Mrs Baxter the Lady hostess of the party—who conducted me and my wife to a couple of chairs under an Arch of Evergreens overshaded by the wide spreading branches of the Lime tree— There was an inscription over the arch, which I did not see— The Revd Mr
Mr Peter Whitney stood near; and all around was a circle of women young and old to the number of about two hundred, with very few exceptions all inhabitants of Quincy— Mr Whitney in the name of the Ladies addressed me by name, and said they had invited me to that party, in token of their respect for my long and eminent public services— Much to my relief he said no more—for more according to the custom which has lately crept in among us from England of beplastering a man with flattery to his face, more would necessarily have been fulsome and unmeaning adulation in the shape of praise— I then addressed the Ladies for about five minutes; thanking them for their kindness, and alluding to the testimonials of approbation and confidence which I had received last Summer from the men of this Congressional District, after the fiery trial of the preceding winter— I said, that this had made a deep and abiding impression upon my heart; but that at the two Sessions of the present Congress new trials of a different character, in which the rights and the reputation of the women of my Country, and particularly of the district, were involved— I stated the number of Petitions which I had received from the several towns in the district from women; the violent outrage by the Chairman of the Committee of foreign Affairs Howard, upon the Petitioners, and the insult upon the sex, which I had felt myself called upon to repel, and the defence of the rights and fair fame of women which ensued— It was to this, I presumed, that I was indebted for the present kind notice of approbation, from the Ladies of Quincy, and to another of a similar nature, in another town of the District— I then made some remarks on the right of Women, to Petition, and on the propriety of their taking a part in public affairs— This was a point to be left to their own discretion, and there was not the least danger of their obtruding their wishes upon any of the ordinary subjects of Legislation—Banks, Currency, Exchange, Sub-treasuries, internal improvement, tariffs, manufactures; public Lands, Revenues and Expenditures, all which so profoundly agitate the men of the Country; the women so far from intermeddling with them, could scarcely be prevailed upon to bestow a thought upon them; and knowing that it was scarcely consistent with civility, so much as to name them in their presence— I now alluded to them only to discard them But for objects of kindness, of benevolence, of compassion, women so far from being debarred by any rule of delicacy from exercising the right of petition or remonstrance, are by the Law of their nature fitted above all others for that exercise.— I said I hoped their right would never again be questioned— I was sure if the Gentleman who I believed in an unguarded and inconsiderate moment had indulged himself by casting the reflection which I so earnestly reprobated, could be present to witness the Scene now before me, he would never again be tempted to express so ungentle a sentiment— I hoped no member of the House of Representatives of the United States would ever again be found to treat with disrespect the sex of his mother, but would feel for every woman the sentiment which I would now tender, in thanks to every female present whether Mother, daughter wife or sister, as expressed in the beautiful lines of an English Orator and Poet

lg.l: “Had I a heart for falsehood fram’d— I neer could injure you;
For though your tongue no promise claim’d— Your charms would keep me true.
To you, no Soul can bear deceit,No Stranger, offer wrong,
But Friends in all the aged you’ll meet— And Lovers in the young.”

div.p: Thus I closed, and then the collation followed.— With many of the women I was acquainted and they introduced me to others— As the Sun went down there was a dance upon the green— The morning had been cold— The Sun had warmed the atmosphere and it was very comfortably warm— Immediately after Sunset however it became again chilly, and the party adjourned to the Ball-room at French’s Hotel, now called the Hancock House— Invitations to the Ball were given us on the ground— I came home and between 7 and 8 accompanied the Ladies to the Ball— The Hall was crowded to excess, and fifty couples were dancing at one country dance— The dancing was universally good, and far more animated than I had seen at private Balls for many years We remained about half an hour after the Evening Ball; and then though much urged to stay to the Supper, came home— The dances were Cotillions, Country dances and fancy dances. No Waltzing— The Ball was continued till between one and two of the morning.— Miss Sampson came here to work for the Ladies, for the remainder of the week.
5. V:15. Wednesday.

I rose this morning with a dull head-ache which continued nearly through the whole day, and disabled me for industrious occupation— I consequently indulged myself in idle visitation of my seedling trees in my garden, Nursery and Seminary—observing them though to no profitable purpose— The observer of Nature should not only discern defects but devise remedies— When I see a tree perish, I should search the cause of its failure and learn to save another of the same kind. But almost all my observation is lost upon me— As an experiment I sawed off a horizontal limb from a button wood tree, grown since August 1834. when I took a horizontal twig from a button wood stake, near the North end of my Nursery, and which was taken up last October then a tree 15 feet high— This is now more than ten feet high— In many other cases of planted, button wood stakes I have failed—but it is a tree of very rapid growth; a forest of which might be raised in twenty years from small stakes cut off from the limbs of a large tree— The Ash, the English white Oak, the red and chestnut Oaks are easy to raise— So are the Horse Chesnut and white Elm, and above all the Philadelphia Maple. I have no doubt that an exceedingly profitable plantation of all these trees could be raised, but it requires twenty years to make the experiment, and I have no prospect of living one fourth part of that time— I despatched the remainder of my pamphlet Speeches, but shall want a great number more— I received a Letter from H. L. Ellsworth, with two copies of the Patent Laws, and Regulations—a Letter from C. T. Thayer, President of the Beverly Lyceum, and one from A. D. Foster, for the Executive Committee of the Worcester Lyceum, inviting me to deliver their introductory Lectures in October and November next— Charles and his wife and family dined with us again— They are going to-morrow to Medford to spend the remainder of the week— After dinner I took a ride with Charles to Braintree and Weymouth— Stoppd at Minott Thayer’s House to return his visit— He said he would send to-morrow afternoon for the Letters recommendatory of Mr Ebenezer
Ebenezer T. Fogg, to the Commissioner of Pensions and to the Post-master General— Evening visit with Charles to Mr T. Greenleaf. Mr and Mrs Appleton were there—and Mrs Greenleaf said they were to remove to the house next door to them—
6. IV:30. Thursday.

I return to my labour of writing, but have an arrearage of diary to fill up.— My morning visit to the trees in my garden, Nursery and Seminary interests me more and more— We have Apples, Pears and Peaches in profusion, the latter, fruit from stones planted by myself— My dwarf tree Apples are now ripe on the tree— Mr David Loud was here again, about his Land-warrant, and the power of Attorney which he sent me to Washington, but after a thorough examination of my papers I have not been able to find them— I told him that I must have left them there with other papers for which I expected to have occasion again and on my return to Washington I would look them up. Deacon Spear was here and I asked him to purchase a Cord of wood on the wharf, and send it to Mrs T. B. Adams— My wife had requested this— He spoke to me about Mr Hobart’s desire to purchase an Acre of land over the Hills; separate from the Mansion house farm; and Mrs Hobart had also mentioned it to me— Hobart he said was willing to give 100 dollars for it; but he rents it now of Carr for 3. dollars a year, and I do not wish to sell it.— Mr Cyrus Farwell a lawyer, an inhabitant of the Western part of the State of New-York brought me a Letter of introduction from Mr Richard Fletcher, the member of the U.S. House of Representatives from Boston.— Mr Farwell is travelling for health and pleasure; accompanied by his brother recently graduated at Middlebury College— The only motive for their visit to me was curiosity to see me, and they staid only a few minutes, and under the same impulse, said they were going to Marshfield to see Mr Webster; and had been yesterday to visit Governor Everett at Watertown—and this morning at the Mount Auburn Cemetery— Charles and his wife went this morning to Medford— About Sunset I strolled over the Hills to look at the red wedge Apple-tree, peculiar in its appearance, and upon which I have attempted the experiment of raising trees from its seeds, as yet, not unsuccessful, but of which I cannot live to taste the fruit.
7. IV. Friday

A sultry Summer day.— I am endeavouring to keep alive, the Pear trees which sprung up on the border between my Eastern door and the gate last year but which Kirk has cropped with his Scythe; together with about half a dozen in the same line of which I dropped the seeds last Summer, and which have come up— I spaded the ground and gave it a dressing this morning—and Kirk took up the weeds from the Summer house cellar.— Horse Plums gathered— Small, but well flavoured. While I am waiting for a further supply from Gales and Seaton of my pamphlet speech, it occurred to me to send a copy of it to the first petitioner of all the petitions and remonstrances against the annexation of Texas to this Union, which were committed to my charge, at the two Sessions of the present Congress— For this purpose it becomes necessary to make out an Alphabetical list of all the Petitioners, at the head of the Petitions; a work upon which I began, with the Petitions presented at the Special Session; of which there were about 400—of which ninety against the annexation of Texas, and the rest, for the abolition of Slavery.— It is slow work and will take me two hours a day for nearly three weeks to complete the Lists for both Sessions— It occupies time too which ought perhaps to be devoted to more intellectual occupations.— But there appears to be a duty of obligation to give to
to the Petitioners who entrusted their Petitions to me, some information of what disposal was made of them—and I propose to send one copy of my pamphlet to the first petitioner, of every petition that I presented against the annexation of Texas— Towards evening, I strolled again in my garden, and Mr Price Greenleaf came in while I was there. He says that forest trees should not be trimmed, but I have experience enough to know that it improves their shape, and hastens their growth— My first morning hour this day was somewhat discomposed— Dr Holbrook had prescribed for my habitual catarrh, a daily draught of five drops of sulphuric acid in a tumbler of water, and I had taken them daily for the last fortnight— To keep the viol of vitriol out of the reach of the children it was hung up on a brass hook just over my wash stand—but the cork of the viol was eaten away, by its contact with the fluid Half drops remaining on the lip of the glass, worked their way to the red tape, and the twine round its neck, by which it was suspended; and decomposed them both It fell in the night; struck on the lower shelf of the stand, broke off at the neck and spilled nearly all the burning fluid over the stand; running over by one of the legs on the carpet turning a circular spot round it of the size of a small saucer black as a coal— I had foreseen this Catastrophe without guarding against it.
8. IV:15. Saturday

Dressing the seedling beds of my six grandchildren, one for each in the front row of the seminary— Trimmed sundry trees, among which one of the Philadelphia maples in the garden— Put into the Post-Office, addressed to Edmund Quincy, one of Mr Legare’s Peace Reports, with my Oration at the Newbury-Port— Call at the Office of the Quincy Patriot, and took the Papers of last Saturday and of this day, and spoke to him of publishing a Letter to the Petitioners and remonstrants against the annexation of Texas to this Union, and concerning Slavery, committed to my charge during the first and second Sessions of the present Congress; and an alphabetical list of the names of the first petitioners, which he promised to do.— My next call was at Josiah Adams junrs. house, where I found him labouring under his annual Catarrh— I told him I had received the answer from the Commissioner of Patents H. L. Ellsworth, to his Letter and mine to that officer, with the description and caveat— That Mr Ellsworth had sent me printed copies of the Patent Laws and Regulations for him— And that 20 dollars must be paid with the entry of the caveat— Returning home, I found my wife and Mary returned from Boston where they went this morning; and Charles, and his wife, back from their visit to Medford; but Abby was unwell, and took to her chamber at her own house— Charles was here in the Evening but she did not come— Mr E. Price Greenleaf passed the afternoon in my Library reading Italian Books—and I had visits from President Quincy, who had come from Cambridge with Mrs Quincy and the widow of Edward King of Ohio, who is now residing with her children at Cambridge for their education—one of her sons having been graduated there at the recent commencement— They came and dined at Coll. Josiah Quincy’s, he being with his family now here: and the President took the occasion to visit me— He said that in a Class of 55 there had been only 5 who had made their option under the new regulations to decline the study of the higher Mathematics
Mathematics— Professor Palfrey was here with his daughter— He came to repeat and urge an invitation that I would prepare for the North American Review of which he is the Editor, an Article upon the Life and writings of William Tudor junr. who was the founder of that literary journal— I told him that I had been unable to prepare such an Article, for want of the principal facts in the Life of Mr Tudor— He promised to furnish, and I promised to furnish the Article, if I could— He wanted me also to furnish an Article upon the Cilley duel, which I declined— Mr Samuel B. Ruggles a member of the House of Assembly of New-York, from the City, and Coll. Astell of the British army, also visited and took tea with us— Mr Ruggles was the author of an excellent report to the Legislature of New-York, last winter, upon internal improvement— He sent me a copy of it which I read with great pleasure— Coll. Astell is an officer of the British army recently imported into Canada; but he says he has received orders to return home— He said he was a grandson of Governor Pownall, concerning whom he was somewhat inquisitive—specially as to the time when he was governor of the Province of Massachusetts Bay.— He thought it had been at the Commencement of our Revolution, but I found on consulting Allen’s New-England biography that its was from 1757 to 1760. between Shirley and Sir Francis Bernard— I told him I had been personally acquainted with Governor Pownall in 1783 and 1784 and had visited him at his then residence at Richmond, in sight of Pope’s house in Twickenham— Mr Ruggles spoke of the approaching elections in the State of New-York; with better wishes than hopes— Charles came after they were gone.
9. IV.30. Sunday

Mr Lunt preached an admirable Sermon— Morning and afternoon from the same text. Luke 17.21— “For behold, the kingdom of God is within you.”— There is a new controversy fermenting in the minds of the younger Unitarian Clergymen in this State, which threatens a further schism in the Christian Church—or rather a renewal of the old problems about matter and Spirit in a new form— Mr Lunt’s argument is that the Christian dispensation is a spiritual regeneration—a system of ideas in the Soul, by the direct agency of almighty power— He rejects therefore the doctrine of Locke that there is no other source of ideas but sensation and reflection— And this system he supposes to have a threefold influence; upon the intellect, upon the sentiments, and upon the conduct of men— The part of the discourse delivered in the morning I thought unexceptionable, eloquent and deeply impressive—the remnant of this afternoon, the application to the points in controversy gave me pause— It seemed to me as if it was bordering on the mystical— The question has often occurred to me what is Faith, and why in the Christian dispensation it is held to be the essential condition of Salvation— The word Faith has several distinct senses even in the Scriptures— It sometimes means only belief— Belief in the Lord Jesus Christ, and in the Truth of his gospel— But belief is not always voluntary— Belief is not at the command of the will— But belief alone is a mere condition of the mind—importing no action; it is an attribute of man’s immortality—no other being upon earth has the capacity to believe— St. Paul defines Faith to be the substance
substance of things hoped for—the Evidence of things not seen— It is therefore not founded upon the testimony of the senses.— It is trust— But Faith in a more enlarged sense is truth to an obligation of duty— And that is its worldly sense. It is the principle of sanctity to the performance of a promise, and this is the sense in which Abraham was the father of the faithful— This is the universal duty of obligation from man to man, and between man and woman— It belongs to the immortal part of their nature, and is the foundation of all Justice, and all morality— Is not the sense also in which Faith is essential to Salvation?— Incorrupta Fides, is much more than mere belief. But I cannot now enlarge— I read the fifth Sermon in the 11th volume of Saurin, and intended to have read the 6th. to make up the loss of the last Sunday—but on returning home from meeting this afternoon I found Mr William Lee who had come to visit us with a boy named Caleb Moore the son of one of his neighbours— He is in feeble health, and told us that he had the Asiatic Cholera since his last visit, on the day of my arrival from Washington.— He walked up with me to Charles’s house, and admired its prospects, but would not stay to tea, for fear of its warming him, and making him take cold in returning home— I walked with Charles to Coll. Josiah Quincy’s where we spent the Evening— He had a new Bible arranged Chronologically, and our conversation was almost entirely scriptural— Mrs Quincy’s aunt Mrs Speakman and the Colls. Sister Sophia were there— He walked the whole way with us to my gate; between 9. and 10. P.M— Evening Aurora Borealis—
10. IV:15. Monday

Morning visit to my Garden, Nursery and Seminary—dressing the children’s beds— Charles went to Boston and returned home to dine— I continue my Alphabetical list of Petitioners at the Special Session of Congress, and made out also a list of persons to whom public documents are to be sent— Henry Hardwick was here; and spoke about ditching between his Saltmarsh land and mine down at the Mount Wollaston farm— I told him I would speak of it to my tenant Alpheus Spear, when he shall be returned from his journey— He also spoke about Mrs Susanna Wood’s pension claim; and I read to him the answer that I have received from the Commissioner of Pensions, to the Letter which I wrote to him enclosing Mrs Wood’s papers— Mrs Wood is Henry Hardwick’s wife’s mother— Morning visit from Dr. John Codman of Dorchester, with Dr Heman Humphrey, the President of Amherst College—where they are now in vacation. Dr Humphrey made some enquiries about the Smithsonian bequest, which he supposed would be applied to the foundation of an University at the City of Washington; but I supposed it would not be appropriated to the education of children— About Sunset I walked up to Charles’s house, and he and his wife spent the Evening here— Miss Sampson returned here this morning.
11. IV: Tuesday.

I was awakened earlier than usual by the noisy travellers to the militia muster and military parade at Dedham— There was from three in the morning till 10 or 11. an incessant racket of Stages Omnibus’s, Chaises, and 8 other vehicles driven with horses. I visited my Plantations—and after dinner I filled the Pot 2 with fresh earth and planted in it the
the seeds of two Bartlett Pear Cores, and of 2 Office Apples.— Counted in the Nursery 6. shagbark walnut trees 7 years old from nuts planted by me in 1830, and all apparently grown to a size, beyond the reach of the winter’s frost.— And I have black, white, red and chesnut Oaks of the same age— With Ash, Chesnut, Horse Chesnut, Elm and Nettle—Pignut—Peach, Apple, Pear and Cherry, Plum, Apricot and Nectarine; but the fruit of these two last, will not come to maturity.— I have also the Currant bush black and red, the filbert, and the Strawberry, grape and blackberry vines— Charles went to Boston, and returned home to dine— He and his wife were here this Evening, and I found myself with a sore tongue, mouth and throat I know not how— The weather was gathering for an equinoctial the whole day but without rain— I answered a Letter from Aaron Clark Mayor of New-York which I have had some time on file and almost finished the Alphabetical list of Petitioners at the special session of Congress, against the annexation of Texas to the United States— Alpheus Spear was here, returned from his expedition for the purchase and sale of black cattle— He said he had been to the western part of the State of New-York, on the borders of Lake Champlain and brought home, about seventy head of oxen, and as many sheep— I spoke to him of the stir made by he borderers owning Saltmarsh adjoining the Mount Wollaston farm for the erection of a fence, and that all was suspended until his return— He said it was nothing but idle resentment of Mr Benjamin V. French; because he, Spear would not yield to his unreasonable complaints— That French himself had filled up the ditch which had formerly been the fence and besides had incroached and mowed upon my land.— He said it was possible that the cattle had once or twice got upon French had talked of suing him for 100 dollars damages— But he had told him he might sue him, and he was very sure he would not recover five dollars, for that would overpay all the damage that he had ever received— If I waited to receive his notification to attend the fence viewers he was confident I should never receive it. Not one of them when it should come to the push, would be willing to pay the expense of making his part of the fence.—
12. IV. Wednesday

The gathering of clouds all day yesterday, and last Evening terminated by a storm of rain, which commenced in the night and continued through the whole of this day and evening with scarcely any intermission— I should have employed the time busily upon engagements of duty, but the sore throat, mouth and tongue, which annoyed me yesterday were far more troublesome this day and attended with a symptom which I had never before experienced— The tip of the tongue was excoriated—the mouth and throat sore, with a coppery taste as of Arsenic, and an almost total extinction of taste in every thing that I ate or drank— The cause of all this remaining a mystery, with a strong suspicion that it was in some way connected with the drops of sulphuric acid which I have taken by Dr Holbrook’s direction in tumblers of water— Another suspicion was that I had drawn all this upon myself by exposing myself bareheaded in my garden, nursery and seminary, morning after morning, in the twilight before sunrise. The
The consequence was that I could think to no purpose, but could only drudge— I answered the Letter from E. R. Tremain Chairman of the Lecture Committee of the New-York Mercantile Library Association; and despatched it with that to the Mayor of New-York; both declining the invitation to deliver the introductory Lecture before them— Finished the Alphabetical List of Petitioners, first signers to Petitions presented by me to the House of Representatives U.S. at the First Session of the 25th. Congress, and re-examined and assorted my files of Letters received in 1837 and 38. in which process I found the Pension Certificate of John Adlington which he had left with me in September last, and in the search for which I had already wasted so much time.— I immediately enclosed and sent it to Mr Jacob H. Loud of Plymouth, who had twice written to me to ask for its return— Without this Certificate the poor man could not receive his pension, and it stung me to the quick that my carelessness in mislaying the document was depriving him of his daily bread— The discovery gave me proportional relief. Miss Sampson departed.
13. II:35 Thursday

The storm continued, increasing in violence, till about half past two O’Clock this morning, when the rain beating against my windows waked me, and I could sleep no more— My mouth, tongue and throat were sorer than ever and I knew I could not lie awake and think till day-light with any tranquility of mind.— I arose, lighted my lamp—drew up my table close to my bedside, and sitting up in bed read for about an hour and a half in the life of Sir Walter Scott— Then dressed and sat down to answer two Letters from William Ladd, President of the American Peace Society— They are to hold a meeting next Tuesday at Boston; and I wish to furnish him in Season with copies which he has requested of Mr Legarés Report to the House of Representatives U.S. on the Peace Society Petitions— I sent also to several members of the State Legislature from the Counties of Plymouth and Norfolk, copies of Mr Tallmadge’s Speech to the Senate on the Sub-treasury, of which I have received about 20 from an unknown hand, for circulation; and with them I have enclosed copies of my Oration of 4 July 1837. at Newbury Port— Several hundreds of these were received here last September after I left home for Washington; and are now here an incumbrance— The morning slipped away— The tempest of wind subsided by the Sun’s rising— The rain continued an hour or two longer to stream and then held up—before Noon the clouds broke away, and at 8 minutes past 6. I saw the last gleam of the sinking Sun, from my Son Charles’s porch a little South of due West— Charles and his wife dined and spent the Evening with us— Before dinner I took to the Post-Office the Packets that I had made up— Visited my garden and Nursery— Found much unripe fruit strewn on the ground wind-fallen; among which a considerable number of the Acorns of the English white Oaks, six of which I planted in the row of seedling beds of my six grand children in the Seminary— I had the old dead stock of the Southern Oak in the middle of the Nursery, sawed off by Kirk, between the two new stocks near the surface of the ground, which sprouted out in the Spring of 1837. from the old Stock, which had been winter killed the Season before.— I was called away from my dinner table
table by a Mr Leeds of New-York with his brother— About two years since he was here speculating upon granite quarries, and in treaty with me, for the purchase of some of my lands— He has since been in Florida, and discovered near St. Augustine a lot of land, I think he said about 8 acres, belonging to the United States, the use of which he wished to obtain gratuitously for the cultivation of the Morus Multicaulis, and the raising of silk-worms— He asked if there was power in the Government of the United States, to grant him this privilege; and if there was, to whom he must apply to obtain it— I said I could not tell whether the Government had the power to grant a gratuitous use of the land without an Act of Congress— That a Bill had been reported at the late Session authorising the President so to dispose of lots of public lands, for the cultivation of silk worms and the sugar beets but had not passed both Houses and become a Law—and I recommended to him to apply to the Secretary of the Treasury for information.
14. III:15. Friday

The weight of years presses me down with constantly growing aggravation, and trifling causes of excitement multiply upon me, which in the prime of life I should not even have felt— Worn out with fatigue by two successive almost sleepless Nights, I took to my bed last Evening before the stroke of the Curfew bell— There was then a feeble radiation of Northern light— About midnight I awoke and looking out at the Eastern window in front of my bed saw a light surpassing that of a full moon, and which I took first for the morning dawn within a quarter of an hour of the Sun’s rising— But I slept again till a quarter past three, when Sirius, was half an hour risen— I brought out Bode’s Uranographia from my closet, laid him on my bed and found the position of Procyon which I had forgotten— Renewed also my acquaintance with Betelgeuse, Bellatrix and Rigel, the three brightest stars of Orion— Then dressed—visited my plantations; finished my Letter to William Ladd, and made up some documents for the Post-Office— Charles went to Boston, and returned home to dine— His house in Boston was broken open, and rifled on Tuesday Night, as that of Edward Miller had been a few Nights before— The same treatment has been experienced by about twenty houses within the last Month and the City authorities slumber over it as quietly as if no such thing had happened— Soon after dinner I had visits from Mr Francis Jackson and Mr Ellis Gray Loring, whose special object was to have a Portrait of me taken, for a company of Gentlemen in Boston—and they requested me to sit for that purpose, to a young promising Portrait Painter from New-York named Page; to which I consented— Mr Loring is to give me notice of the time and place, which is proposed to be next week at some house in Boston— They were succeeded by Mr Bancroft the Collector of the Customs at Boston, with two young men by the name of Smith, who came to take me by storm for a Lecture to the Lyceum.— Bancroft always an egregious flatterer so beplastered me with praise, and the intense desire there was to see and hear me in Boston, that I scarcely knew how either to keep my temper, or to resist his importunities. I finally made a sort of conditional promise to attend a meeting of the Lyceum, some day in October— I understand this anxious desire to see and hear me, is something like the Passion of a crowd, to see an Execution— There is no good will to me in any party at Boston— I
I am obnoxious to them all; and to the last gasp of my life am doomed to hold my course in opposition to them all— These gentlemen all took tea here. And we had evening visits from Mr and Mrs Lunt and from E. Price Greenleaf— Mrs Smith and Mary dined with Abby, and they all spent the Evening at Mrs T. B. Adams’s— My tongue, mouth and throat continue ulcerated, and my taste nearly gone—
15. IV. Saturday

Visit to the plantations— Dressing my Grand children’s Nursery Beds— Yesterday I planted sundry Bartlett Pear and Office Apple seeds in the border between the Althaea and Horse Chesnut trees, from the door to the front gate— My wife and Mary went with Charles and his wife to Boston, to set the house in order which has been broken open, ransacked and laid under contribution— They returned home to dinner— Mrs Smith was unwell, and kept her chamber the whole day— An insane young man, who said he was called by the name of James Day came on horseback to the house, and said he had come from New-York, for the sole purpose of engaging my services as a lawyer, for two purposes—first to obtain satisfaction for excessive ill-treatment which he had received from certain members of the Legislature of the State of Illinois at Vandalia—and secondly to obtain possession of a bequest of ten Millions which had been left him by his real father in a foreign country— The injury done him at Vandalia, was in administering to him medicines, to deprive him of his reason and induce him to commit suicide, and thereby to rob him of his rights— He had actually been reduced to that state and had made the attempt, but his life had been saved, and he had become convinced that it was better for him to live. As to those who had injured him in Illinois, he might have challenged them to meet him in the field; but he did not approve the practise of dueling— He thought it better to take the course of the Law, and had come to engage my services which he hoped I would give without requiring a retaining fee— I told him I was not and had not been for more than thirty years in the practice of the Law; but asked if he had no relatives, connections of the persons who had passed for his Parents— He said there were such relatives but they could be of no use to him— His supposed Parents whose name he bore were dead— I enquired of his age—he said it was thirty— That he had been some years in business as a merchant in the City of New-York; very successful; and in which he had amassed an handsome property; but that in the troubles which came on two years ago, he had been unfortunate—had lost all he had, and become unable to meet his engagements— He had therefore gone to seek his fortune at Vandalia, and there had met with this injurious treatment— I enquired who it was that he believed to be his father, and to have left him the bequest— He said “an individual of the Bonaparte family”— I said then it must be Jerome; the only individual of the family who had been in this Country more than thirty years ago— No; it was not Jerome—who then? Napoleon— But he was never in this Country— Nor do I believe I was born in this Country, but was brought here in childhood— It is known that Napoleon had several children, and made provision for them by his Will— I want my right, and nothing but my right— If I am the son of Napoleon I am entitled to the Crown of France, and if I am entitled to it, I want it— I saw Mr Webster yesterday, and he advised me to apply to some lawyer in the State of Illinois— That was the best
best advice that he could give you, and I give the same— But in the whole State of Illinois there is not a single lawyer in whom I can have a particle of confidence— This was the substance of his conversation— I repeated that not being in the practice of the Law, it was not in my power to assist him.— He thanked me courteously for my advice; mounted his horse and went off— Josiah Adams junr. sent his Son, with a 20 dollar bill to forward to the Commissioner of Patents for his caveat— Towards Sunset I strolled over the Hills to the red wedge Apple tree, from the fruit of which I wish to raise seedlings, and have already some from seed, saved in October 1836.— The fruit is not yet ripe. Call at Charles’s. His wife so much fatigued that she could not come over to our house for the Evening—but he did.
16. IV. Sunday.

Returned last Night to my bed chamber, and rose this morning at four— There was a remnant of Northern light which might have been mistaken for the dawn— There was a Northern light the Evening before the late storm of rain, and every evening since— Half an hour before the morning service, surprised me with a visit—85 years of age. He came with Dr Henry Ware junr. Professor of Pulpit Eloquence, and the Pastoral care at the theological Institution at Cambridge, who preached by exchange with Mr Lunt— His morning text was from Proverbs 4.23. “Keep thy heart with all diligence: for out of it are the issues of life.”— That of the afternoon from Matthew 16.26. “For what is a man profited, if he shall gain the whole world and lose his own soul? or what shall a man give, in exchange for his soul?” Dr Ware junr. is the eldest Son, of my old chum of 1786. the Hollis Professor of Divinity at Harvard University, and like him one of the salt of the Earth— His discourses were both excellent, and presented a striking and impressive parallel between the Spirit and the flesh— The body and the Soul— The perishable and the immortal part of man’s nature— Dr Waterhouse dined with us— I invited, and very earnestly pressed Dr Ware, but he declined; labouring under a severe sick head-ache, which he said disabled him from all other exertion, and all possibility of partaking in conversation or the pleasures of Society— He went to Mr Lunt’s— Doctor Watehouse went with him after the afternoon service; and they barely stop’d at our gate on their return towards Cambridge, to take Dr Waterhouse’s Cloak— The Doctor at table this day told my wife that the first time he had ever seen me was at Passy, standing between the knees of Dr Franklin, wearing a light blue coat with read facings, and that Samuel Cooper Johonnot was also there— This had altogether escaped my memory; and the circumstances fix the time between January and July 1780. The light blue and red uniform was that of Mr Pechigni’s school— The first recollection that I have of the Doctor was some months later in the same year about the beginning of December at Amsterdam, when the Doctor was a medical student at Leyden, and persuaded my father to send me and my brother Charles there with Mr John Thaxter— The Doctor is now tottering into his grave; but the chances are at least equal that I shall precede him in the transition to the world of Spirits— I read the 6th. Sermon in the 11th. volume of Saurin chiefly on the words of Jesus, “my kingdom is not of this world”— There is a remarkable passage of sharp censure upon Machiavel and Hobbes for maintaining that the duties of Christian Charity are not applicable to men in public stations, but only to individuals in their private capacity.— Mrs T. B. Adams sent me word that she wished to see me upon business, and I walked there— It was to ask me to see and converse with Mr Luther Angier whom she expected here to-morrow, concerning the sale of the Medford Farm— Walk home. Norhern Light
17. V. Monday

Fire in the dining room— Cold and damp with occasional sprinkling. I have made an alphabetical list of the members of the Legislature of this Commonwealth, who signed the memorial of the Peace Society, referred on the 26th. of March last to the Committee of Foreign Affairs, and I send to as many of them as my supply will permit copies of Mr Legare’s report for the Committee, made on the 13th. of June last; packing up with each copy, of the Report, one of my 4th. of July Oration delivered at Newbury-Port— It absorbs much time— My visits to my plantations occupy more— I found this morning that all the fine peaches in my garden, which were approaching to maturity had vanished from the trees— Kirk thought it strange that Sunday Night should have been selected for the operation; but it is the favourite Night for them— The Peaches are in profuse abundance, but are disappearing like the morning dew— I staked a twig of the garden button wood, in the ground near it— Mr Luther Angier of Medford was here. Mrs T. B. Adams’s agent for the Medford and Braintree farms— He spoke of young Souther’s enquiries of the price for which it would be sold, and enquired whether I would consent to its sale— I stated to him that my brother had mortgaged to me both those Estates for the payment of bona fide debts due from him to me— That he had retained the possession of them during his life, and that his wife’s right of dower was not renounced in the Deeds— That after his decease I took possession of them, to hold them legally in fee, but really in trust for his widow during her life, and for his surviving children in common after her decease— She has accordingly received all the rents and profits of them since my brother’s death; and now if the Estate at Medford can be sold, and the proceeds immediately re-invested upon security equally good and yielding better profit, I would readily give my consent and execute the necessary deeds. I thought Mr Souther who wants to make the purchase should make his offer and as there are 38 acres and a dwelling house, the price should be from 4 to 5000 dollars— Mr Angier said he had been this morning to the Braintree Estate and had seen Mr Capen, who seemed much inclined that Mrs Adams should be at the expense of digging a ditch to preserve his meadow from being overflowed— I filled pot 3. with fresh earth and planted in it Bartlett Pears, and Dwarf and Office Apple seeds with a central whole large black plum from Medford— Charles and his wife spent the Evening here— Mrs Smith continues confined to her chamber.
18. IV: Tuesday.
Large Eclipse of the Sun.

Thick fog nearly through the whole day: discomposed the dressing of my grand children’s Nursery beds— Planted a circle of Peach-stones round Fanny’s bed with Pear Cores and Office and dwarf Apple-seeds. I have covered all my vacant grounds with seedlings so that I have scarcely an inch left for new ones— Charles went to Boston and returned home to dinner. I have received a Letter from James Herring at New-York pressing for the biographical notice of my father for the compilation, and there is, notice in the Quincy Patriot of last Saturday, that a Letter from me may be expected in the next— I am not ready with the Alphabetical list of Petitioners, and therefore determined to address a
a short prefatory Letter to the Editor of the Patriot, to satisfy his promise of a Letter next Saturday, and get another week for the list of Petitioners— I begin, but could not finish the Letter— I went to Charles’s House, and took the 8th. volume of Sanderson’s biography of the signers of the Declaration of Independence, which I wish to consult for some of the facts of my father’s life— Charles brought me from Boston the Rapport sur l’Etat de l’Instruction Publique dans quelques pays de l’Allemagne, et particulierement en Prusse, par M. V. Cousin, Consuller d’Etat, Professeur de Philosophia, Membre de l’Institut, et du conseil royal de l’instruction publique—Nouvelle edition—Paris 1833—and Mrs Sarah Austin’s English translation of the part of the same relating to Prussia—London 1834.— The fog was so thick that I had foregone all hope of seeing the eclipse until near four O’Clock, when it partially cleared away and exposed the black outline of the Moon passing from North to South over the Sun’s disk— It continued visible till near the time of greatest observation 40 minutes past 4. I went over to Charles’s house and upon his porch viewed it through the Spy-glass and with the naked eye— The fog thickened again however and intercepted altogether the sight— The darkness occasioned by the eclipse was scarcely perceptible. The evening was so damp and dark that Charles and his wife did not come over I am still despatching copies of Legare’s Peace Petition Report; and with it, of my Newbury port Oration— Mrs Smith continues confined to her chamber
19. V. Wednesday

I finished the Letter to the Editor of the Quincy Patriot, and took it to his Office for publication in the next Saturday’s paper— Midshipman Joseph H. Adams came from Charlestown and dined with us— He said he wished to go with Commodore Hull to the Mediterranean. That he had called yesterday upon the Commodore at his lodgings, and asked a recommendation of him to the Secretary of the Navy— He said he should be very glad to have him with him, but he had not applied to the Secretary in behalf of any other Officer, wishing to avoid any appearance of partiality and had advised him to request a recommendation from me; which I immediately wrote and sent to the Post-Office— I wrote also to H. L. Ellsworth Commissioner of the Patent Office, and had exchanged the Quincy Bank 20 dollar bill which Josiah Adams junr had sent me to pay for entering his caveat; for a Bill of the same amount of the Pennsylvania Bank of the United States—to enclose it in this Letter— Charles and his wife with his daughter, and John Quincy dined with us, as is the standing rule for every Wednesday. I am making a collection of Miscellaneous pamphlet publications of my composition; with the intention of making up sets for each of my grandchildren— I make out here one set of twenty-six from which there are missing 13 which I recollect, some of which it would be impossible for me now
now to recover— This evening was beautifully clear— I saw the Sunset from the Northwestern corner of the porch in front of Charles’s house at 5 minutes before 6. by my Chronometer—and we both sought in vain for the sight of the new moon— The eclipse having been from 3 to 5 yesterday afternoon I wished to ascertain whether the moon could be seen so soon after the conjunction— Neither Charles nor I could discover her— Though when the new Moon has been in the morning, I have often seen her on the Evening of the next day—
20. IV:15. Thursday
O Boston— Page— Quincy.

On rising this morning I saw Venus, about a quarter of an hour risen, behind the easternmost of the two barns, and approaching the Sun— Near her were two Stars which I did not recognized and I believed one of them might be Mercury—visible as morning Star from this time till the 4th. of October. By resorting to Bode’s Uranographia, and observing the pointers of Ursa Major, and the Polar, I saw that the Northernmost of the two Stars was in right line was about equidistant South of them with the Polar North; and ascertained them to be Regulus the Lion’s heart, and his neighbour of the second magnitude— I had not the remotest suspicion of the Lion’s being there— I intended to have seen the Sun rise from Charles’s house, but as it set last night 5 minutes before 6 by my Chronometer, I supposed it would rise 5 minutes after six this morning—but it rose 20 minutes before 6, and was about five minutes above the horizon when I reached the corner of the house— I went into Boston with Charles— Called at the Albion House to see Commodore Hull, but he was out at Abbott Lawrence’s to see him; but he was at the Store—at N. 22 School Street, where Mr Page took the first sitting for my Portrait; an hour and a half— Mr Ellis Gray Loring was there nearly all the time— Second sitting to be Saturday Morning at 9—if I can go into Boston— I purchased a Bible at a Bookstore, and took it away forgetting to pay for it; but soon recollecting myself returned and paid— At Frobisher’s, Silversmith’s, bespoke a silver ring for the Cane from the wood of the Frigate Constitution, given me by Commodore Isaac Hull, and 3 dozen of Silver Spoons— Visit to Dr George Parkman, who shewed me some copies from Pictures of Raphael, painted on glass, by the rediscovered art of the middle ages which he has received from Munich— Also some extremely beautiful engraving of Flemish paintings of Gabriel Metzu, and Mieris in Lithography— He engaged me to dine with him next Tuesday at 3. O’Clock— And he walked with me to Hawley place where the Horse and 4 wheel’d Chase were put up, and where I met my Son— We returned home to dinner— After which Mrs Lydia, widow of Caleb Faxon came with another Lady to enquire about her pension claim— The last Law limits the pension right to widows married before the 1st. of January 1794— She was married only 13 days later, and does not see the propriety of her being excluded from the right— She will petition at the next Session of Congress and will send me her papers, of which I promised to take charge— E. Price Greenleaf was here the remnant of the afternoon, and visited with
visited with me my garden and Nursery— Charles and his wife spent the Evening with us— My sore throat and tongue were more troublesome than they had yet been— I returned to my library bed-chamber.
21. III:30. Friday
Autumnal Equinox.

A gloomy day— My tongue mouth and throat still very sore; and my taste as yet very imperfectly restored. In the morning before the rain came on, I planted 11 whole Office Apples in row fronting the East side of the Nursery as a border distant from the fence, from a seedling elm of the third year to the corner opposite to the gate— Before dinner I went to put the Letter for H. L. Ellsworth into the Post-Office, and called at the Quincy Patriot Office to enquire if the proof of my Letter to the Editor to be published to-morrow was ready— It was not, but he sent it to me in the Evening, and I corrected it. There was only one word misprinted, but that was an absurdity— I was caught in a drenching shower; the first of a series which finished by heavy rains in the Evening— Charles nevertheless spent it with us; but his wife could not come— It being the day of the Equinox I went to Charles house in the morning to Charles’s house to see the Sun rise; but he rose beclouded and invisible— I resumed the biographical notices of my father, but wrote in a sluggish, and disspirited temper— Read about 20 pages of the life of Walter Scott— There was another bright Aurora Borealis last Evening— [symbols]
22. IV. Saturday
My grandson John Quincy Adams’s birth day— 5.

Heavy rain this morning till 8. it then held up; but with such threatening aspect that I did not go into Boston— Wrote a page or two in the biographical notices of my father,—for Mr Herring— Received from Washington 80 copies of my revised fragment Speech, of which I despatched about 50 to the members of the Convention of Delegates from the towns of the 12th. Congressional District of Massachusetts, held at Quincy on the 23d. of August 1837. and with each of them one copy of the old Colony Memorial Republication of my Letter of 13. August 1838. to my Constituents— At Noon I went to Charles’s house, and gave to his Son John Quincy a Bible, as I have done heretofore to each of my 3 granddaughters— I have but one book said poor Collins, in his last days—but that is the best— I wish all my grandchildren to remember after I am gone, and as long as they shall live, that of my birth-day presents to them, the best of books was the one most highly valued by myself— What their destiny in life may be, and what their characters and merits, is known only to the great disposer.— To him I address my daily and nightly prayer, that their lives may be pure, pious, prosperous and useful to their Country— And of this I have no doubt; that if they shall by the blessing of God attain the age of maturity, their virtues, their usefulness and their success in life will be proportioned to the attachment of the Soul, the unbidden and sincere attachment which they shall form for the pages of this book— I fear that the taste and the relish for it cannot be taught or commanded— It must be voluntary and spontaneous. Nor is it
is it a disposition to be paraded or displayed before men, but an homage of the heart to be yielded in humility before God— Mr Peter C Brooks came out to spend the Sunday with his daughter and her family. I dined with them— After dinner Mr Brooks took a ride with Charles to Braintree and Weymouth. I passed the first part of the Evening with them, and they the latter part with us— My sore throat and mouth are healing; and my taste promising to return—
23. V:30. Sunday

My Son Charles’s third son, born on the 16th. of February last was baptized this morning by Mr Lunt by the name of Henry Brooks. The ceremony was performed immediately before the commencement of the morning service; the child was held up at the font by his father and mother— Mr Lunt preached from Hebrews 12.14. “Follow peace with all men: and holiness, without which no man shall see the Lord:”— The discourse was confined to an exposition of the better part of the text—and it was admirable— By holiness, Mr Lunt understands sincere and habitual piety— The first part of the verse prescribes the duty of man to man, and sums it all up in the injunction to follow Peace with all—but holiness is the purity of the heart, whence all virtuous action proceeds, and by seeing the Lord is that exquisite enjoyment which is exclusively reserved to the immortal Soul— Mr Brooks and Charles dined with us; as did Mr Degrand who came out from Boston, and spent the day here. We rode to and from Meeting this afternoon in the midst of an heavy rain. Mr Lunt’s Sermon was from Mark 7:11. [“]But ye say, if a man shall say to his father or mother, it is Corban, that is to say, a gift, by whatsoever thou mightest be profited by me: he shall be free.” These last words are added in the English translation— There is something of obscurity in the text; of which Mr Lunt gave an explanation— The discourse was against hypocrisy as exemplified by the Pharisees— Late in the Evening a cold Northwestern sky-scraper, cleared up the atmosphere— I read the 7th. Sermon of the 11th. volume of Saurin— A continuance of the series upon the Passion of Christ. The text is from the 5th. to the 12th. verse of the 23d chapter of Luke; but the main stress of the discourse is upon the words [“]il emeut le Peuple,” he stirreth up the People; and the argument is upon the false imputation of exciting sedition cast upon Jesus Christ, and always applied to great reformers— The preacher compares and conciliates the passages in which Jesus himself declares that he came not to bring peace but the sword; and to set the members of the same family at variance with one another with those in which he gives the precepts of universal benevolence— And he acutely discriminates between the disorders imputable to the doctrine—and those resulting from the passions of those to whom the doctrine is addressed— This is one of the remarkable Sermons of the collection—containing much matter applicable to the present times.
24. V. Monday

Mr. Brooks returned home this morning. A clear cold autumnal day.— My hoarseness and sore breast continues—but I am gradually recovering my taste— I was afraid of visiting much my garden, nursery and seminary owing
owing to the dampness of the ground—but the leisure of the day was absorbed in completing the alphabetical list of Petitioners, whose Petitions were presented by me to the House of Representatives of the United States at the special Session of Congress last fall— Morning visit from Mrs Mercy Tufts with her daughters Mrs Tarbell and Susan Tufts— She reminded me that she had been present at the commencement when I took my degree of bachelor of Arts at Cambridge—but seemed surprized when I observed that it was 51 years ago.— I rode with Charles this afternoon round through Milton, returning by the way of the hill— Mrs Smith, Mary and Abby spent the Evening at Mrs T. B. Adams’s. E. Price Greenleaf and Charles with us— My granddaughter Louisa quite unwell— I received a Note from Dr. George Parkman, postponing his invitation to me to dine with him to-morrow; he being called away to attend the sick-bed of his wife’s mother Mrs M’Donough at Hingham
25. IV. Tuesday.
Boston. Page— Plymouth Stage— Quincy.

Went into Boston with my Son, and gave a sitting of 3 hours to Mr Page, whose manner of painting is different from that of any other painter who has taken my Portrait— The first sitting, he took the outlines of the face in Charcoal; and this day he fitted up the space between the lines with a thick daubing of oil colours— It has no pleasant aspect, but his finished Portraits of Harding the Painter, of Mrs Ellis G. Loring and two other Ladies which he has at his room, give proof of no ordinary talent— While he was at work, Dr George Parkman came in, and sat about an hour— He spoke of the treatment that he had received in England from Daniel O’Connell which he thought very rude— Upon his introduction to the Irish Orator, he enquired from what part of the United States he came and being answered from Boston, reproached him with the burning of the Convent; and the refusal of indemnity to the sufferers— Dr Parkman told him that the facts of that event had been misrepresented to him, and that the truth was very different— There is however no satisfactory apology for that transaction, as it bears upon the character of the People and of the time— Pudet haec opprobria non potuisse refelli— It was near one when I left Mr Page’s room— Call at the Post-Office, and found that the 1000 copies of my fragment Speech had been received and delivered to the order of my Son— At his Office, he was not quite ready to go on the return home.— I went to the Anti-Slavery Office and Book-store of Isaac Knapp, who informed me that he had received the copies, and had authorised Gales and Seaton to draw upon him at three months sight for payment— He enquired if the pamphlet was stereotyped— I said no, but I believed the Press was kept standing— He said he thought he should soon dispose of these copies and want more— I said there was no copy-right, and I had given a conditional permission to the Executive Committee of the American Anti-Slavery Society at New-York, to publish an edition of it, if they should
should wish; on condition that they should not countermand the orders they had given to Gales and Seaton for 1000 copies— After calling at two or three shops to enquire for long cotton stockings which one of the shopmen told me, had gone so much into disuse that they would not pay for the expense of keeping them for sale, I returned to Charles’s Office, and waited for him a half an hour, till near two O’Clock— The tenant of the Southernmost of my two houses corner of Boylston Street, came to call upon Charles for repairs.— After waiting sometime longer I went to the Stable— Charles after waiting for me sometime, had just gone— I went back again, found he was not at the Office— Just then the Plymouth stage went by, in which I took a seat, and at 20 minutes past 3 was landed in front of Mr Daniel Greenleaf’s yard at the Cross-roads— Charles had got home about a quarter of an hour sooner.— My family had just sitten down to dinner. After dinner I called at the Quincy Patriot Office, but Mr Green was gone to Boston— Stop’d at Mr Gill the bookbinder’s shop, and was going to Charles’s when I met him coming over. Mrs Smith, Mary and Abby spent the Evening at Mr Miller’s— A drowsy head-ache drove me to bed at 8 O’Clock.
26. I and IV:30 Wednesday

I awoke in the middle of the Night, and no stars being visible knew not what the time was, till on lighting my lamp I found it just one in the morning— After spending about half an hour in directing to sundry persons copies of my fragment Speech I returned to bed and obtained relief from a bad head ache and two hours more of much disturbed repose— I then shortly after 4 rose and made progress in the biographical notice of my father— Mr George Newcomb came to make enquiries whether I will deliver a Lecture to the Quincy Lyceum and when— I promised to do it if possible on the 17th. of this month— The meet once a week on Wednesday Evenings to hear a Lecture or for debate— I gave him a copy of my Speech, having sent one yesterday to his father James Newcomb, one of the selectmen of the town— Charles and his wife dined, and spent the Evening with us.— The weather confined us all to the House—on consulting the Journal of the Convention in 1779 which formed the first Constitution of the Commonwealth of Massachusetts, it started so many enquiries that after consuming about two hours upon them, I was obliged to give them all up and desist— My father was a member of that Convention and of the Committee that drew up the Declaration of Rights and the Constitution of Government— But he sailed for Europe before they were debated in the Convention— His draught is lost— The newspapers of this day announce the death of Dr Henry Huntt at Washington, and of the Clerk of the House of Representatives of the United States, Walter S. Franklin.
27. III:30 Thursday

I have undertaken to finish for Mr James Herring the biographical notice of my father long since undertaken— But the only way in which I shall be able to accomplish it will be to devote the morning, from my rising hour till breakfast to it, without intermission— I began accordingly and wrote two pages, which I set myself as my daily task till the work is
is done— I had this morning no temptation to go out, for it poured with rain, and a chilling North-eastern gale— It had rained without intermission all night, and continued till near noon— I examined two or three of my Chests of papers and found several printed miscellanies to be added to the volumes of my works which I am compiling— Despatched about 30 copies of my fragment Speech— Deacon Spear was here this afternoon, and said Mr Benjamin V. French had been to him again very impatient for the fence, on the Salt-marsh— Lemuel Brackett objects to making a fence, and I desired Deacon Spear to say to Mr French, that if a fence was to be made it must be by regular notification from the fence viewers— I wrote 3 short Letters excusatory, to James Herring at New-York, to Tyler Bigelow at Boston, and to C. T. Thayer at Beverly— At 7. this Evening I went with my wife, Charles, his wife and Mary, to the gratuitous concert of Mrs Vollentine and her pupils— Many fashionable songs with accompaniment on the violin— The room was greatly crowded—we came home between 9 and 10.
28. IV. Friday

By steady exertion, I wrote my two pages of biography before breakfast and went with Charles to Boston.— Gave another sitting of three hours to Mr Page for my Portrait— While he was at work Mr Isaac P. Davis, Mr Clevenger and Dr Parkman came in— After the sitting Dr Parkman walked with me, and I paid visits to Mr Samuel T. Armstrong who was not at home, and to Mr Thomas L. Winthrop who received me. He read me part of a Letter from Dr Galindo, at Guatemala, concerning the ruins of the city of Copan in Central America— I returned to Charles’s Office where I found him at one— Took at Frobisher’s shop my cane, under the head of which I have had placed a silver ring, with the following inscription— “Isaac Hull to John Quincy Adams— Live Oak, from U.S. Frigate Constitution. 1836.” The cane is of one piece, and was given me by Commodore Hull about two years since; and I have had it encircled with this ring to preserve the memorial of the donation— We came home to dinner, and I found Julia De Wint at our house. She dined and spent the Evening here; and then returned to Mrs T. B. Adams’s— After dinner I received visits from Revd. Mr Charles Follen, and Mr Charles Edward Rawlins, an English traveller, who brought me a Letter of introduction from Edward P. Cranch at Cincinnati— Mr Follen spoke of the Peace Convention held last week at Boston, where a new Society was formed by the name of the New-England Non-resistance Society, with a Constitution prepared by William Lloyd Garrison— Its principles are those of the Quakers in their utmost extent— Dr Follen could not subscribe to them— I gave him one of my fragment Speeches— I planted sundry Peaches and Plums and Stones— But the wetness of the ground curtails my labours— Charles and his wife spent the Evening here.
29. IV:15 Saturday.

Rain almost all night, and the greater part of this day: and after a severe drought of several months, the earth within the last fortnight has been saturated with water. My biographical notices continue, with too much carelessness in writing— Passed Midshipman Joseph H. Adams came this morning, and informed me that he had last Evening received the order from the Secretary of the Navy to join the ship Ohio, bound to the Mediterranean under the command of Commodore Hull— He was obliged to return immediately to his station at the Navy yard in Charlestown— I wrote this afternoon four short Letters, still leaving arrears of tedious correspondence— Towards evening the rain having subsided into fog, I walked to Mrs T. B. Adams, to give Elizabeth a Letter from her brother, Isaac Hull. Found there Mrs Phineas Foster with her son George, and her daughter Fanny— They had just come out from Boston, and were immediately to return— With them went Mrs Boyd, heretofore Susan Harrod, with her boy about 5 years old— I had not seen her before, since her marriage— Julia De Wint also came in from Mr Edward Miller’s, where she is staying with his daughter Hannah— I came home at the dusk of Evening— Charles and his wife spent it here— Their son John is unwell.
30. V. Sunday.

A fine autumnal day after a long succession of foul weather Mr Lunt’s morning Sermon was from Matthew 28.19. [“]Go ye, therefore, and teach all Nations baptizing them in the name of the Father, and of the Son, and of the Holy Ghost.”— I suppose this Discourse was composed, or now preached, in consequence of the baptism of my Son Charles’s boy Henry Brooks, last Sunday. Mr Lunt gave in it an exposition of his understanding of the meaning of the text— He disclaimed all belief in the doctrine of the Trinity, without however discussing it. His explanation of the text was satisfactory to me, though not to the trinitarians, who are quite as inaccessible as the believers in the kindred doctrine of transubstantiation— Mr Lunt’s opinions upon the nature and duties of Christian baptism, and particularly of those who hold up their children for baptism, were cogent and impressive— His afternoon discourse was from 2. Peter 1.7. “And to godliness brotherly kindness; and to brotherly kindness charity.”— The leading idea of which was that the principle of Christian morality was the accumulation of all the social virtues— Returning from Meeting this afternoon I stopped at Charles’s house to see his son John who has been some days unwell— His mother was about to take him out to ride— I read the 8th. Sermon of the 11th. Volume of Saurin, upon the despair of Judas—and the 9th. upon the calamities of the Jews predicted by Jesus at the time of his crucifixion— I read the latter to supply the omission of the 2d. of this month.— I read also some pages of the preface to Basnage’s Histoire des Juifs

Day. I rise between 4 and 6. O’Clock— Sometimes between 3 and 4.— Dress and write till 8—with occasional morning visits to my Garden, Nursery and Seminary Breakfast— Mail Letters, and Newspapers with transient casual visitors till 1/2 past 2 or 3— Afternoon miscellaneous occupations till Sunset— Tea for my family and conversation with them till 1/2 past 9— Bed about 10.
